abstract: For some employees at Citigroup, the mess at the bank can be found in its fridges and on its fax machines, as well as in its finances — so that’s where they’re cleaning up.
snippet: For some employees at Citigroup, the mess at the bank can be found in its fridges and on its fax machines, as well as in its finances — so that’s where they’re cleaning up.
lead_paragraph: At Citigroup, it seems, progress is measured in awfully small doses. The bank’s chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, has spent months stitching together a turnaround plan, yet he has been dogged by mess after mess since he started. Some federal regulators question whether he is up for the task. Executives are exhausted after months of long hours, stress tests and bailouts. Bankers are anxious about corporate life under the thumb of Citigroup’s single largest shareholder: the United States government.

headline.main: Tackling Problems Big and Small at Citigroup
